required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Sleepiness and the Effects of CPAP on Salivary Cortisol and Alpha-Amylase Levels in Patients With Sleep Apnea
clinical_study.official_title: Sleepiness and the Effects of CPAP on Salivary Cortisol and Alpha-Amylase Levels in Patients With Sleep Apnea

brief_summary.textblock: Patients with Obstructive Sleep Apnea Syndrome (OSAS) will evidence higher levels of salivary cortisol and alpha-amylase levels prior to use of placebo and continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and will evidence a decrease in these levels after consistent use of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) therapy as compared to placebo. Their level of sleepiness will also decrease with the use of CPAP therapy and will correlate with the levels of salivary cortisol and alpha-amylase in relation to their subjective sleepiness scale, Psychomotor Vigilance Test (PVT), and pupillometry.

detailed_description.textblock: It has been shown that there is an inconsistent response in serum cortisol levels in patients with Obstructive Sleep Apnea Syndrome (OSAS), but it is undetermined whether a change in hormone level was not seen due to compliance issues in these long-term studies. These investigators will be employing compliance monitoring continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) machines and also assessing "sleepiness" before and after therapy. Sleepiness is the dependent variable in our study and will be measured subjectively using sleepiness scales and objectively using Psychomotor Vigilance Test (PVT) and an autonomic measure using pupillometry prior, during and after treatment.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Difference between Baseline(Day 0) and Average of Day 1,7,14.
primary_outcome.description: Salivary Cortisol was measured by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. The reference range for healthy adults is <4.2 nmol/l. Samples were collected at ~7am and ~11pm on each Day: 0, 1, 7 and 14 through a salivary swab.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Difference between Baseline(Day 0) and Average of Day 1,7,14.
primary_outcome.description: Epworth Sleepiness Score (ESS) is a scale to assess sleepiness during waking hours. The scale ranges from 0-24 with higher scores indicative of greater sleepiness.

secondary_outcome.description: Salivary Cortisol was measured by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. The reference range for healthy adults is <4.2 nmol/l.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adults
- Male and female
- Between ages 18 and 90
- Undergo a Polysomnography (PSG) with evidence of any sleep disordered breathing including snoring, mild/moderate/severe sleep apnea, and/or restless legs
Exclusion Criteria:
- Ages 17 and under
- Pregnant women

clinical_study.keyword: Sleep Apnea and/or any Sleep Disordered Breathing

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Participants were recruited from sleep clinic patients scheduled for polysomnography.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Participants without prior treatment of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) or overt airway structural pathology that would interfere with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) were recruited.

group.title: 14 Days of Placebo Therapy
group.description: 14 days of placebo therapy - use of guaifenesin with salivary cortisol measurement and Epworth Sleepiness Score (ESS) documentation

group.title: 14 Days of Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) Therapy
group.description: 14 days of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) therapy with salivary cortisol measurement and Epworth Sleepiness Score (ESS) documentation

group.title: All Study Participants
group.description: Participants received 14 days of placebo therapy then 14 days of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) therapy

measure.title: Apnea-hyponea Index (AHI)
measure.description: AHI<5 Normal <=5 AHI <15 Mild Sleep Apnea 15<= AHI <30 Moderate Sleep Apnea AHI>=30 Severe Sleep Apnea

measure.title: Body Mass Index
measure.description: <18.5 Underweight range >=18.5 BMI <24.9 Healthy weight range >25.0 BMI < 29.9 Overweight range >30.0 BMI <29.9 Obese weight range

outcome.title: Salivary Cortisol Level
outcome.description: Salivary Cortisol was measured by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. The reference range for healthy adults is <4.2 nmol/l. Samples were collected at ~7am and ~11pm on each Day: 0, 1, 7 and 14 through a salivary swab.
outcome.time_frame: Difference between Baseline(Day 0) and Average of Day 1,7,14.
outcome.population: We have made a best faith effort from a manuscript to determine the primary outcome measure; Salivary Cortisol Level; but access to the primary data has been lost and it additionally cannot be found in the manuscript. Despite all efforts to contact the PI/study team members, the statisticians and date are gone.

outcome.description: Epworth Sleepiness Score (ESS) is a scale to assess sleepiness during waking hours. The scale ranges from 0-24 with higher scores indicative of greater sleepiness.
outcome.time_frame: Difference between Baseline(Day 0) and Average of Day 1,7,14.

measure.title: Epworth Sleepiness Score (ESS)
measure.description: Epworth Sleepiness Score (ESS) is a scale to assess sleepiness during waking hours. The scale ranges from 0-24 with higher scores indicative of greater sleepiness.

outcome.title: Salivary Cortisol in Participants Who Used Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) at ~7am, Day 0
outcome.description: Salivary Cortisol was measured by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. The reference range for healthy adults is <4.2 nmol/l.
outcome.population: A sub-analysis was performed on those using CPAP>= 3 hours per night compared to those who used CPAP< 3 hours per night

group.title: CPAP>= 3 Hours Per Night
group.description: The average nightly CPAP use in the group using CPAP for >=3 hours (N=9) was 311 minutes (180-444) minutes.

group.title: CPAP<3 Hours Per Night
group.description: In the group using CPAP for <3hours (N=9), it was 33 minutes (2-85) minutes.

measure.population: A sub-analysis was performed on those using CPAP>= 3 hours per night compared to those who used CPAP< 3 hours per night

reported_events.time_frame: Adverse Events were observed in a non-systematic way over the course of approximately 6 years the patients were enrolled.
reported_events.desc: Given the minimal risk nature of this study, adverse events were collected via a non-systematic assessment. The primary risks were loss of confidentiality, some possible discomfort from the mask and the possibility of an adverse event related to the mucolytic, guaifenesin. None of these possible adverse events occurred and they were not collected in a systematic way.

group.title: 14 Days of Placebo Therapy, Then CPAP
group.description: 14 days of placebo therapy: 14 days of placebo therapy then 14 days of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) therapy

group.title: 14 Days of CPAP Therapy
group.description: 14 days of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) therapy

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: The limitation of this trial is the results were entered strictly from a manuscript published in 2011. Despite repeated attempts to reach out, the original study team members, statisticians and data are no longer available.
